questions.question: Question 1: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for carcinoma cervix?
questions.explanation:
HPV serotypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with carcinoma cervix. Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include: • Human Papilloma virus (most important) • Sexual intercourse before 18 years • Multiple sexual partners • Multiparity • Poor personal hygiene • Smoking and drug abuse • Women with STD, HIV, HSV • Immune suppression 837 
Sold by @itachibot Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or southern blot or Hybrid capture technique is used for HPV 
DNA detection.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not true regarding HPV?

options.a: E1 and E2 are viral proteins needed for replication
options.b: E6 and E7 are viral proteins needed for malignant transformation
options.c: E6 acts via the retinoblastoma gene
options.d: HPV 16 is the most common serotype causing carcinoma cervix

questions.explanation:
E6 acts via the tumor suppression gene p53. It increases proteasome-dependent p53 
degradation. E7 binds and acts via the retinoblastoma (Rb) gene. The viral E6 and E7 oncoproteins encoded by the high-risk type HPVs (such as HPV 16 and HPV 
18) are necessary for malignant transformation. E1 and E2 oncoproteins are responsible for viral replication.

questions.question: Question 3: Which is the HPV serotype most commonly associated with carcinoma cervix?
questions.explanation: HPV 16 is the most common type associated with carcinoma cervix. Associations between human papilloma virus (HPV) serotypes and carcinoma cervix: • Most common serotype - HPV 16 • Most malignant serotype - HPV 18 • Most specific serotype - HPV 18 • Most common serotype associated with • Squamous cell carcinoma - HPV 16 • Adenocarcinoma - HPV 18 Cancers caused by HPV: • Male - penile, oral, anal • Female - cervix, vagina, vulva

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 5: HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes?
questions.explanation:
HPV nonavalent vaccine (Gardasil 9 or HPV9) is active against HPV 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58. Currently, HPV nonnavalent vaccine has replaced Gardasil which is a quadrivalent vaccine acting

questions.question:
Question 6: A 45-year-old patient comes with repeated infections of trichomonas vaginitis, her physician 
advises for a Pap smear. She asks you regarding the purpose of this test. What would be your 
appropriate response?

options.a: It is a screening test for cervical cancer
options.b: It is a diagnostic test for trichomonas infection
options.c: It helps to diagnose cancer in her genital tract
options.d: It helps to diagnose other associated genital infections in her

questions.explanation:
A pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. It is not a diagnostic test (option C). The 
presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by colposcopy, cervical 
biopsy, or fractional curettage. If trichomonas is reported from Pap testing, it should be confirmed by saline microscopic 
preparation (option B). Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a Pap smear 
every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and Pap co-test every 5 
years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious 
PAP, screening till 75 years. HIV+ women should have annual checkups until three consecutive 
negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life. 839 
Sold by @itachibot Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and 
the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have 
intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation. Procedure: • The patient is put in a dorsal position, and the labia are parted • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayer’s spatula: • Bifid end - ectocervical sample • Blunt end - vaginal cytology • Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush • The sample is spread on a glass slide • The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol • Stained with Papanicolau stain or short-duration Papanicolau stain (SPS). 840 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 24-year-old woman comes to the gynecology OPD for a routine Pap smear. The 
histopathology slide is shown below. Identify the cell marked as "A". 830 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The cell marked A is the superficial cell. ACOG guidelines recommend cervical exfoliative cytology every 3 years starting 21 years as 
screening for cervical cancer. The image below shows a superficial cell (a) and an intermediate cell (b): The image below shows parabasal cells (marked by black arrows): 841 
Sold by @itachibot Koilocytes are epithelial cells that contain eccentric, hyperchromatic, moderately enlarged nucleus 
that is displaced by large perinuclear vacuole. It is a feature of HPV infection.

questions.question: Question 8: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Various systems of classification are used to describe cervical cytology after Pap smear such as: • Papanicolaou classification - describes the exfoliative cytology of the cervix in a Pap smear. • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) - histopathological description of how much of the 
thickness of the cervical epithelium is replaced by dysplastic cells • Bethesda classification - it is another method to describe cervical dysplasia The various systems and their corresponding classes are given below: 842 
Sold by @itachibot where, CIS: Carcinoma in situ, CIN: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, SCC: Squamous cell 
carcinoma, SIL: Squamous intraepithelial lesion, ASCUS: Atypical squamous cell of undetermined 
significance, HPV: Human papillomavirus. Bethesda system Pap classification (1943) 
Cervical intraepithelial neopl

questions.question:
Question 9: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is 
the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
The appropriate management of a 45-year-old with a positive pap smear and post-coital bleeding 
is a colposcopy-directed biopsy. A per speculum examination must be done whenever a female comes with post-coital bleeding in 
order to evaluate for carcinoma of the cervix. If growth is visible, a punch biopsy should be done, 
and else if no growth is visible, then a pap smear is done. A pap smear is a screening test for 
cervical cancer. The presence of abnormal cells/ a positive test requires further evaluation by 
colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage. Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a pap smear 
every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and pap co-test every 5 
years. Women should stop having cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If a pap 
smear is suspicious, then screening is continued till 75 years. HIV+ve women should have annual 
checkups until three consecutive negative tests followed by testing every 3 years for life. Pap testing should be done prior to vaginal examination. Lubricants should not be used and 
the patient should not be menstruating during the pap test. The patient should not have 
intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. The ideal time is around ovulation.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old sex worker presented with irregular menses, post-coital bleeding, and 
occasional foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She was advised to undergo a Pap smear. What is 
the best time for this investigation?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of cervical carcinoma. The best time to do a Pap smear is 
around ovulation, but it can be performed at any other time as well. Prerequisites of doing a Pap smear: • It should be done prior to vaginal examination • Lubricants should not be used • The patient should not be menstruating during the pap test 843 
Sold by @itachibot • The ideal time is around ovulation • The patient should not have intercourse 24hrs prior to the test. Based on Pap smear findings, dysplasia of cervical cells is graded using various classification 
systems such as WHO grading, CIN grading, and the Bethesda system.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is false about Schiller's test?

options.a: Lugol's iodine is used to paint the cervix
options.b: The epithelium is stained mahogany brown
options.d: It detects the presence of glycogen in the epithelium

questions.explanation:
The abnormal cells remain unstained on performing Schiller's test. Schiller's test, also known as VILI (visual inspection with Lugol's iodine), involves painting the 
cervix with Lugol's iodine. It is used to detect any abnormal cytology in the cervix and vagina, 
such as in cases of carcinoma cervix. The normal vaginal and cervical epithelium contains glycogen, therefore stains mahogany brown 
on being painted with Lugol's iodine. The abnormal cells remain unstained. These areas need to 
be biopsied and sent for histopathological examination.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following would you not expect to see in the colposcopic biopsy of a patient with 
cervical intraepithelial neoplasia?
questions.explanation:
The basement membrane is intact in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). Features of CIN: • Varying degree of dysplasia • Altered nuclear-cytoplasmic (N:C) ratio • Hyperchromatic nuclei • Mitotic figures • Intact basement membrane. 844 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following methods is most commonly used for the treatment of CIN?

options.b: Large loop excision of transformation zone

questions.explanation:
Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LLETZ) is the most commonly used treatment 
option for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). It is also known as loop electrosurgical excision 
procedure (LEEP). It is applicable for the treatment of CIN anywhere in the lower genital tract. This uses electric 
current through a monopolar wire electrode to either cut or coagulate cervical lesions. Like other 
excisional procedures, it is done in the immediate post menstrual phase. The procedure involves minimal patient discomfort, cost, and complications. Since it can be 
performed using local anesthesia, it has become the primary outpatient treatment modality for 
high-grade cervical lesions.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which among the following is the treatment of choice when microinvasion of cervix neoplasia 
is suspected?
questions.explanation: Conization is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is suspected. • Indications of conization • Endocervical dysplasia • Transformation zone is not completely visualized • When there is discrepancy of findings between cytolology, colposcopy & biopsy • Microinvasion is suspected • Indications of hysterectomy • Older & parous women • Uterus is associated with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed • Recurrence or persistent lesion • In-situ adenocarcinoma cervix

questions.question:
Question 15: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the 
management?
questions.explanation:
Colposcopy with LEEP would be appropriate management for CIN III. Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) is an opd procedure done under colposcopic view 
and local anesthesia.Here, a low voltage current is passed through the loop and a cone of tissue is 
removed from the cervix. This procedure causes minimal bleeding and the tissue removed is sent 
for histopathological examination (HPE). This is the treatment of choice for CIN 2&3 of any 
age and parity. 845 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: Which is the most common malignancy in women in India?
questions.explanation:
Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women in India as well as globally. Cervical cancer is 
the most common genital cancer in India. Lip and oral cavity cancer is the most common malignancy in men. Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include: • Human Papilloma virus (most important) • Sexual intercourse before 18 years • Multiple sexual partners • Multiparity • Poor personal hygiene • Smoking and drug abuse • Women with STD, HIV, HSV • Immune suppression

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is false regarding the transitional zone?

options.c: Nabothian cysts mark the original site
options.d: It is limited to external os

questions.explanation:
The transitional zone or squamocolumnar junction is well outside the external os during the 
reproductive period. It is the site where the squamous epithelium lining the vagina merges with the columnar 
epithelium of the endocervix. The original squamocolumnar junction is marked by the presence of 
Nabothian cysts and glandular openings. It is a dynamic part and moves with age and hormonal influence: • During pregnancy and with oral contraceptives, it pouts out of os. • Following menopause, it gets indrawn inside the os. The cells here are highly sensitive to irritants, mutagens and viral agents such as HPV. Cancer 
screening using Pap smear involves scraping this area and studying the cells for nuclear changes.

questions.question: Question 18: Identify the false statement regarding adenocarcinoma of the cervix.

options.a: Most common site is transformation zone
options.b: Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer among women in India

questions.explanation: The most common site of adenocarcinoma is endocervix. It commonly occurs in young females and OCP users, and is associated with HPV 18.

questions.question:
Question 19: You would suspect and evaluate for carcinoma cervix in patients presenting with which of the 
following conditions?
questions.explanation:
846 
Sold by @itachibot Patients with carcinoma cervix most commonly present with metrorrhagia, now known as 
intermenstrual bleeding. Post-coital bleeding is the most specific symptom of carcinoma cervix.

questions.question: Question 20: What is the most common site of hematogenous metastasis of cervical cancer?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of hematogenous metastasis of cervical cancer is the lung. About 1-2% of patients with cervical carcinomas present with lung metastases, and 5-35% 
eventually develop lung metastases. Other common sites of blood-borne metastases include bone, liver and bowel.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 65-year-old woman comes for follow-up a few months after surgery for carcinoma cervix. 
On evaluation, she is found to have a recurrence of the malignancy. Which of the following is 
true about her condition?

options.a: Most common site of recurrence is pelvic lymph node
options.b: Mortality in patients with recurrence is due to pulmonary embolism
options.c: Treatment involves surgery with lymph node dissection
options.d: Recurrent tumor with largest diameter <3cm has good prognosis

questions.explanation:
A recurrent tumor with the largest diameter of <3cm is associated with a good prognosis. The extent of recurrent disease and involvement of pelvic lymph nodes are prognostic factors for 
survival. An isolated central pelvic tumour with no involvement of the pelvic sidewall also has a 
good prognosis. Most recurrences are seen within 3 years and the prognosis is poor with uremia being the most 
common terminal event. Recurrences most commonly involve the pelvis than the para-aortic or 
pelvic lymph node. All patients with a suspected recurrence should undergo PET/CT for evaluation and biopsy for 
confirmation. Treatment involves either radical chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration. Concurrent 
chemotherapy with cisplatin and/or 5-fluorouracil may improve the outcome.

questions.question: Question 22: Identify the true statement about the staging of cancer cervix.

options.a: Clinical examination is the first step in staging
options.b: Tumor markers are important for diagnosis of metastasis
options.c: CT scan is the best method to assess principal tumors
options.d: MRI is the best method to assess nodal metastasis

questions.explanation:
Clinical examination is the first step in staging carcinoma cervix. Clinical examination was the principal method in staging until the 2018 FIGO guidelines which 
recommended the use of imaging and histological investigations when available. USG, CT, MRI, 
and PET-CT can be used to assess the extent of the tumor, nodal status, and local or systemic 
spread. MRI is the best method to assess the principal tumor while PET-CT is the best method to assess 
nodal metastasis. FIGO no longer mandates biochemical investigations, such as tumor markers, for diagnosis of 
metastasis. 847 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: The CT of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper 
part of the vagina and parametrium. What is the stage of the disease?
questions.explanation:
The stage of cervical carcinoma is II B as it involves the upper part of the vagina and 
parametrium.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 50-year-old woman presented to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding. She was 
diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage IB after evaluation. What is the treatment of choice for 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type III hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in carcinoma cervix - stage IB. It involves radical 
hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy and para-aortic lymph node evaluation. Stage IB is defined as a macroscopic lesion still confined to the cervix, with the depth of invasion 
5mm. It is the first stage in which lesions become clinically visible. Hysterectomy types include: • Type I - Simple / extrafascial • Type II - Modified radical / Wertheim • Type III - Radical / Meigs-Wertheim • Type IV - Extended radical Hysterectomy • Type V - Exenteration.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 30-year-old woman is found to have a lesion in the cervix which is 7mm wide and has a 
depth of 4mm. She has one child and wishes to preserve fertility. What is the most 835 
Sold by @itachibot appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
The woman has stage I A2 cervical cancer and the most appropriate management is radical 
trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy. Radical trachelectomy is a fertility-preserving surgical procedure. This involves the removal of the 
entire cervix and parametrium. Cervical conization with laparoscopic or extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy is an alternative 
that also preserves fertility.

questions.question: Question 26: Which among the following are contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix?
questions.explanation:
Post-menopausal status is not a contraindication for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix. Contraindications for radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix include: • Pelvic inflammatory disease • Young patient (to preserve ovarian function) • Associated myoma, prolapse, ovarian tumor, genital fistula • Vaginal stenosis • Adenocarcinoma or adenosquamous carcinoma – surgery preferred. 848 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:

carcinoma cervix. What is the dose to be administered at point B?
questions.explanation:
In the treatment of carcinoma cervix, the dose to be administered at point B is 6000 cGy. Radiotherapy in carcinoma cervix: Point A
